Starting with part (a): What's the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to the parent? Since the organism is heterozygous for all five genes, self-fertilization would mean each gamete has a 50% chance of being either the allele from the mother or the father. But since both parents are the same (heterozygous), all gametes are equally likely. Each gene pair is independent, right? So for each gene, the probability of getting the correct allele is 1/2. Since there are five independent pairs, I think we multiply the probabilities together. That would be (1/2)^5 = 1/32. Hmm, but wait, does that make sense? Let me see. Wait no, actually, when you self, you're making a gamete choice at each gene. So for each gene, the chance of correctly pairing is 1/2, but since all genes are independent, it's indeed (1/2)^5, which is 1/32. So option E says 1/32, which seems right.

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

(b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Wait, but let me double-check. For each gene, the probability that it is homozygous is 1/4 (AA) + 1/4 (aa) = 1/2. Since all genes are independent, the combined probability is (1/2)^5 = 1/32. So part (b)'s answer would be 1/32 as well.

Now part (c): Assuming complete dominance, what proportion of the total progeny will show the dominant phenotype for all five characters? Complete dominance means that the presence of even one dominant allele results in the dominant trait. So, for each gene, the dominant phenotype occurs if at least one copy is present. So for each gene pair, the probability of showing the dominant phenotype is 1 - (probability of both recessive). The probability of both alleles being recessive for one gene is (1/2)*(1/2) = 1/4. So the probability of at least one dominant allele is 1 - 1/4 = 3/4. Since the genes are independent, the probability for all five genes is (3/4)^5. Calculating that: 3^5 = 243, 4^5 = 1024, so 243/1024. Looking back at the options, option E is 243/1024, so that must be the answer.

(a) Probability of identical genotype: 1/32.

(b) Proportion of homozygous: 1/32.

(c) Proportion with dominant phenotype: 243/1024.

Looking at the options provided, option E matches all three answers.
